conclusion: A coordinate system with V (volume) on the vertical axis and T (temperature) on the horizontal axis
Point A is at coordinates (T₀, V₀)
Point C is at the origin (0, 0)
The line BC, when extended, passes through the origin
AB is parallel to the V-axis (horizontal line)

premise: AB is parallel to the V-axis (horizontal line)
conclusion: The gas changes from state A to state B along a horizontal line. Since the line is horizontal (constant T), this is an isothermal process at temperature T₀.
Pressure at point A: pₐ = p₀, Temperature at point A: Tₐ = T₀

premise: Points A and B lie on the same isotherm (T = T₀), and this is an ideal gas. For an ideal gas at constant temperature, pV = constant.
pₐVₐ = pᵦVᵦ, Vᵦ = 2V₀, Vₐ = V₀, pₐ = p₀

For an ideal gas, the first law of thermodynamics states: Q = ΔU + W. For an isothermal process in an ideal gas, the internal energy depends only on temperature. Since temperature remains constant, ΔU = 0.

conclusion: The heat absorbed by the gas during the process from state A to state B is 10 J.
